gurmukhi: AYsy hI idvs bqIq kIey suK so duKu pY iknhU nhI pwXo ] kMcn Dwm bnY sB ky su inhwir ijnY iSv so llcwXo ]
transliteration: Aise Hidivas Bateet Keee Soukh So Doukh(u) Kinhoo Nahipaayo|| Kanchannddhaam Bade Sabh Ke Su Nidaar(i) Jinai Shiv So Lachadyo||
translation: In this way, the days passed off comfortably and no one was inflicted with sufferings; the golden mansions were made in such a way that even Shiva could have coveted for them on seeing them;

gurmukhi: ieMdR qXwg kY ieMdRpurI sB dyvn lY iqn dyKn AwXo ] duAwrvqI hU kau sXwm BnY jdurwie BlI ibD ibEq bnwXo ]1962]
transliteration: Indra Tyaag Kai Indrapurisabh Devan Lai Dekhan Aayo|| Duaarvatihu Kau Syaam Bhanai Jaduraae Bhalibidh Biot Banaayo||1962||
translation: Indra leaving his city alongwith the gods came to see this city and the poet Shyam says that Krishna had designed very nicely the outline of this city.1962.

gurmukhi: ieiq sRI dsm skMDy ibcMqR nwtk kiRSnwvqwry smwpqm ]
transliteration: It(i) Sridasam Sakandhe Bachitra Naatak Krishnaavatdare Samaaptam||
translation: End of the Chapter “Building of the city of Dwarka” in Krishnavatara based on Dasham Skandh in Bachittar Natak.
Now begins the description of the Marriage of Balram

gurmukhi: AYsy kiRSn bqIq bhu idvs kIey suKu mwn ] qb lg ryvq BUp iek hlI pwie ghy Awn ]1963]
transliteration: Aise Krishan Bateet Hahu Divas Keee Soukh(u) Maan|| Tab Lag Revat Bhoop Ik Halipaae Gade Aan||1963||
translation: In this way, Krishna, passed off many days in peace and comfort; after that a king named Rewat came and touched the feet of Balram.1963.

gurmukhi: nwm ryvqI jwh ko mm kMinAw ko nwm ] khXo BUp su pRsMin hÍY qwih brY blrwm ]1964]
transliteration: Naan Revatijaah Ko Mam Kanniaa Ko Naam|| Kahyo Bhoop Su Prasann(i) Hvai Taah(i) Darai Balraam||1964||
translation: “The name of my daughter is Rewati and I request that Balram may wed her.”1964.

gurmukhi: BUp kI XO suin kY bqIXw blrwm Gno icq mY suKu pwXo ] bXwh ko jor smwj sBY iqh bXwh ky kwj qbY auT DwXo ]
transliteration: Bhoop Kiyau Soun(i) Kai Bateeyaa Balraam Ghano Chit Mai Soukh(u) Paayo|| Byaah Ko Jor Smaaj Sabhai Tih Byaah Ke Raaj Tabai Outh Dhaayo||
translation: Hearing these words of the king, Balram was extremely pleased and taking with him, other members of his brotherhood, started immediately for marriage; started immediately for marriage;

gurmukhi: bXwh kIXO suKu pwie Gno bhu ib`pn lokn dwn idvwXo ] AYsy bXwh hulws bFwie kY sXwm BnY Apny giH AwXo ]1965]
transliteration: Byaah Keeyau Soukh(u) Paae Ghano Bahu Bippan Lokan Daan Divaayo|| Aise Byaah Hulaas Badhaae Kai Syaam Bhanai Apne Grah(i) Aayo||1965||
translation: The marriage was solemnised happily, and caused the Brahmins to be given the gifts in charity; in this way, after the marriage ceremony, he returned to his home delightfully.1965.

gurmukhi: jb pIA qRIA kI Er inhwirE ] Coty hm ieh bfI ibcwirE ] iqh ky hlu lY kMDih DirE ] mn Bwvq qw ko qnu kirE ]1966]
transliteration: Jab Peea Treea Kior Nihaario|| Chhodhe Ham Eh Badibichaario|| Tih Ke Hal(u) Lai Kandhah(i) Dhario|| Man Bhaavat Taa Ko Tan(u) Kario||1966||
translation: When Balram saw towards his wife and found that he himself was smaller and she was taller in size; seeing this he placed his plough on her shoulder and according to his desire fashioned her body.1966.
